Your telegram No. 133 [of June 21st: Philippine proving flights to Madrid from Manila and back]. No objection on the part of United. Kingdom authorities to landings at Rangoon. Foulds D. 10.12 a.m. 21st Jane 19L7. No, 133 21st June 1947 R. 7,00 a.m. 21st June 1947, Repeated to Department of External Affairs, New Delhi to*31 Governor of Burma. CONFIDENTIAL YYYY v.v'AMr JfcJi glegrams No s. 83 and 90, Philippine flights to India, Note dated June 19th from Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs requests permission for ’’landing permits for two round trips” from Manila to Madrid and return via Rangoon Calcutta and Karachi. These journeys are to be made by Philippine Air Lines Incorporated, the first flight leaving Manila on or about July 2nd the second on or about August 5th. 3. Although described as ’’two additional proving [sic] flights” these projects, following those referred to in my^telegram under reference, seem designed to develop into a regular service. I am not sure whether we could object provided stops are purely non-traffic, 4, I request instructions as to reply which you wish me to return. F&reagn Qffie-e—plea-se pass -to NevrDeThir-a-ftd Rangoon as my telegrams Nos. 31 and 1, [Not repeated to New Delhi pending Departmental instructions]. [Copies sent te Telegraph Branch India Office for .^petition to ^Governor. ofR-Burma j.With the compliments of the Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs Copies also sent to /<l Foreign Office, ^ 194 '\ 8B [ 33281 — 3 ]CODE. I DEPARTMENTAL HO, 1. PROM MANILA TO FOREIGN OFFICE. His Majesty's Consul General. f%~ 85 - D. 5.15 p.m. 2nd April 1947. R. 12.55 p.m. 2nd April 1947, 2nd April 1947, Repeated to: Department of External Affairs, New Delhi. H r :W:W:W;W Philippine flights to India. Following is substance of note which I have received todajr from Department of Foreign Affairs. [Begins], .Philippine Airlines Incorporated request permission to extend air service to India landing at Calcutta and Karachi. Company propose to offer service on non-scheduled basis. As first step the Company desire to conduct series of experimental flights to places named. [Ends], 2. I have already informed the Department of Foreign Affairs of decision of Government of India regarding an earlier application by another Philippine air company for permission to open a scheduled service. This decision was that Government of India could not agree pending receipt from Philippine Government of proposal for a bilateral agreement (despatch from Department of External Affairs to Manila dated February 24th). T T should be grateful to receive Government of Inaia s instructions by telegraph regarding the present application.FILE copy. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: Coll 5/61(1) ‘Survey Flight to Europe by Phillipine Aircraft’

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 16; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file consists of requests from the Government of the Philippines, relayed by HM Minister at Manilla (Linton Harry Foulds), requesting temporary landing rights in Burma and India for a number of charter flights to Europe.The file includes a divider which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
